docs.abstract: The banking and financial services giant is the first on Wall Street to create gun control policies after the massacre in Parkland, Fla.
docs.snippet: The banking and financial services giant is the first on Wall Street to create gun control policies after the massacre in Parkland, Fla.
docs.lead_paragraph: Citigroup is setting restrictions on the sale of firearms by its business customers, making it the first Wall Street bank to take a stance in the divisive nationwide gun control debate.

headline.main: Citigroup Sets Restrictions on Gun Sales by Business Partners
headline.print_headline: Where Others Fear to Tread, Bank Imposes Gun Measures

docs.abstract: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase offer no details on how they plan to remake health care. Some experts attempt to imagine what they’ll do.
docs.snippet: Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase offer no details on how they plan to remake health care. Some experts attempt to imagine what they’ll do.
docs.lead_paragraph: The fledgling plan from Amazon, Berkshire Hathaway and JPMorgan Chase to create an independent health care system for their American employees is just as bare-bones as it is bold.

headline.main: ‘Dr. Alexa, I’ve Been Sneezing and My Throat Is Sore’

docs.abstract: Walmart’s abrupt shuttering of 63 Sam’s Club stores as it revealed higher pay leads to condemnation from customers and departures to Costco and BJ’s.
docs.snippet: Walmart’s abrupt shuttering of 63 Sam’s Club stores as it revealed higher pay leads to condemnation from customers and departures to Costco and BJ’s.
docs.lead_paragraph: The conventional wisdom is that consumers do not go to brick-and-mortar stores anymore.

headline.main: Loyal Sam’s Club Members Lament the Loss of a Trusted Friend
headline.print_headline: Loyal Sam’s Club Members  Lament Store Shutdowns

byline.original: By Tiffany Hsu and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: Active shooter trainings, security cameras and “behavioral threat assessment teams” try to avoid or mitigate office attacks like the one at YouTube.
docs.snippet: Active shooter trainings, security cameras and “behavioral threat assessment teams” try to avoid or mitigate office attacks like the one at YouTube.
docs.lead_paragraph: The laid-back companies of Silicon Valley are known for corporate headquarters that resemble universities, where employees mingle with tourists taking selfies and collaborations take shape out on the quad.

headline.main: YouTube Shooting Puts a Focus on Workplace Security
headline.print_headline: Reconsidering Office Safety In Shooter Era

byline.original: By Tiffany Hsu and Jack Nicas

docs.abstract: Metal detectors, remotely locking doors, bulletproof backpacks and more: Schools are being swamped with pitches for little-researched security products.
docs.snippet: Metal detectors, remotely locking doors, bulletproof backpacks and more: Schools are being swamped with pitches for little-researched security products.
docs.lead_paragraph: The best way to shield a school from a gunman is to have a metal detector. Or doors that can be remotely locked. Or Twitter-trawling bots looking for threats. Or bulletproof clipboards, whiteboards and backpacks.

headline.main: Threat of Shootings Turns School Security Into a Growth Industry
headline.print_headline: With Schools as Targets, Security Outfits Flourish

docs.abstract: The idea of combining CBS and Viacom has created quite a drama. The characters include a once-estranged father and daughter and the executive that turned around a network.
docs.snippet: The idea of combining CBS and Viacom has created quite a drama. The characters include a once-estranged father and daughter and the executive that turned around a network.
docs.lead_paragraph: The power struggle over the futures of CBS, home to the most-watched television network in the country, and Viacom, which owns cable channels like MTV and Comedy Central, is marked by family politics, strong egos and relentless competitive pressure.

headline.main: Behind the Battle Over the Future of MTV and ‘Big Bang Theory’

docs.abstract: The mall staple, known for its ear piercing service, is trying to shed $1.9 billion in debt and close underperforming stores.
docs.snippet: The mall staple, known for its ear piercing service, is trying to shed $1.9 billion in debt and close underperforming stores.
docs.lead_paragraph: For four decades Claire’s jewelry chain has been a fixture at malls and shopping centers, piercing the ears of millions of American teenagers.

headline.main: Claire’s, the Teen Jewelry Chain, Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
headline.print_headline: Claire’s, Staple of Malls, Files for Bankruptcy

docs.abstract: The social media company posted robust revenue and user growth in its latest quarter. It made it easier to buy ads and may have benefited from Facebook’s troubles.
docs.snippet: The social media company posted robust revenue and user growth in its latest quarter. It made it easier to buy ads and may have benefited from Facebook’s troubles.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Snap finally snapped its losing streak.

headline.main: Snap Reverses Slide as User Growth and Revenue Jump
headline.print_headline: Snap Reverses Slide as User Growth and Revenue Jump

docs.abstract: Travis VanderZanden, chief executive of electric scooter start-up Bird, is unperturbed by how San Francisco and other cities are in an uproar over the dockless vehicles.
docs.snippet: Travis VanderZanden, chief executive of electric scooter start-up Bird, is unperturbed by how San Francisco and other cities are in an uproar over the dockless vehicles.
docs.lead_paragraph: VENICE, Calif. — Travis VanderZanden, the chief executive of electric scooter company Bird Rides, surveyed the new indoor park at his office one morning this week.

headline.main: Electric Scooters Are Causing Havoc. This Man Is Shrugging It Off.
headline.print_headline: Charged Up Over Scooters Despite Uproar

byline.original: By Nellie Bowles and David Streitfeld

docs.abstract: Using a tool that Facebook offers its users, our columnist found out more than he wanted to know about the social network, the ad industry and himself.
docs.snippet: Using a tool that Facebook offers its users, our columnist found out more than he wanted to know about the social network, the ad industry and himself.
docs.lead_paragraph: When I downloaded a copy of my Facebook data last week, I didn’t expect to see much. My profile is sparse, I rarely post anything on the site, and I seldom click on ads. (I’m what some call a Facebook “lurker.”)

headline.main: I Downloaded the Information That Facebook Has on Me. Yikes.
headline.print_headline: Remember Those Friends You Deleted Long Ago? Facebook Does
